title: 113_s274
content: The "Children Eating Well Act" may also be referred to as the "CHEW Act." It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The "Children Eating Well Act" or "CHEW Act" defines terms like elementary school, local educational agency, secondary school, and State educational agency. It also defines programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education. These programs aim to enhance students' ability to choose and consume healthy foods, consider various influences on healthy eating, and provide education for making healthy eating decisions. The "CHEW Act" aims to enhance students' ability to make healthy eating decisions by considering influences on healthy eating and providing education using scientifically sound and developmentally appropriate nutritional materials supported by the Dietary Guidelines for Americans. The "CHEW Act" includes professional development programs for teachers, school staff, and food service workers to promote healthy eating and nutrition in schools. The "CHEW Act" includes programs to promote healthy eating and nutrition education. Local educational agencies receiving assistance under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 must develop and implement programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in schools. This may include integrating such programs throughout the school day and using educational materials to emphasize healthy eating. Local educational agencies must develop and implement programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in schools, including integrating these programs throughout the school day and using educational materials to emphasize healthy eating, balanced diets, and physical activity for student wellness. Local educational agencies are required to integrate healthy eating and nutrition education programs in schools, focusing on a variety of activities to improve student knowledge and skills without emphasizing weight loss. They must also periodically monitor schools' efforts in promoting nutrition understanding and healthy eating. Consultation with various stakeholders is necessary for developing and implementing these programs. The paragraph emphasizes consulting multiple viewpoints, including families, students, school officials, and community members, to develop and implement programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education. Collaboration with organizations with nutrition expertise is also highlighted for guidance and assistance in program development and implementation. Working with various stakeholders, including nutrition experts and government authorities, to develop and implement programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in schools. The Act of 2008 (7 U.S.C. 2036a) provides technical assistance for designing programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in schools. This includes working with wellness councils, integrating programs with school wellness policies, and providing professional development on nutrition education for staff members. The Act of 2008 provides technical assistance for promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in schools, including working with wellness councils, integrating programs with school wellness policies, and providing professional development for staff members. Each State educational agency must submit a report on programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education, and an inter-agency task force will review nutrition education. The Secretaries of Education, Agriculture, and Health and Human Services will establish a task force to review and recommend effective nutrition education programs for schools. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2014 through 2019.
